Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Biometric Data Analytics Platform to Enhance Mental Health Provider-Patient Engagement
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide a digital health solution that empowers both patients and providers to engage in meaningful and personalized treatment. The market that this proposal has the ability to reach is significant and includes a medical/clinical segment, a research segment, and a performance segment. This approach has the potential to improve patient care while reducing healthcare costs. Additionally, as education of patients and the public improves regarding mental health, the negative stigma surrounding these conditions will decrease and more people in need will seek care. An initial application will be in treating Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, where there is an urgent and critical need for innovation. Engaging patients in their treatment plans will have a positive impact on the lives of those suffering from mental illnesses.

This I-Corps project is an innovative approach that provides easy to interpret results tailored to mental health providers, patients, and other non-technical users. The software aggregates data from numerous modalities, allowing for more complex and valuable analyses than existing platforms. The physiological data being collected has been scientifically proven to be related to mental well-being. Furthermore, clinicians are able to gain deeper insights into their patient's physiological response in real-time and over the course of a long-term treatment plan to guide clinical decision making. Existing barriers to treatment are addressed by providing seamless connection to various wearable devices, HIPAA-compliant architecture to ensure data privacy, pairing to audio recording or virtual reality environments, real-time note taking abilities, and simultaneous multi-session overlay. Engaging patients in their treatment plans through an objective measurement tool addresses a clear gap in mental health treatment, which is currently heavily reliant on subjective questionnaires and self-reporting.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the duration of the NSF I-CORPS program, our team interviewed 108 medical professionals to explore the potential for commercialization of NeuroFlow's digital health platform that analyzes real-time patient data through a variety of inputs relating to mental state. There are several stakeholders who would benefit from this platform, including clinicians and patients. The aim was to understand and identify optimal customer segments to enable commercialization efforts.


Initial customer segments included private practices and hospital systems focusing on behavioral health with the assumptions of insurance coverage having an impact on patient care decisions. While the engagement and compliance features in our platform resonated with behavioral health clinicians, we found the cost savings per patient and the potential for accelerating treatment via remote patient monitoring were appealing to providers. We quickly learned mental health clinicians don’t always accept insurance due to the low reimbursement rates, however non-behavioral health clinicians are more likely to accept insurance. Additional potential customer segments expanded to payors, community behavioral health and physical health settings. We additionally sought input from medical professionals in these segments, such as primary care physicians and pain providers.


After speaking with these additional segments, we learned many providers aren’t familiar with new CPT codes surrounding behavioral health (Current Procedural Terminology - a medical code set that is used to report medical, surgical, and diagnostic procedures and services to entities such as physicians, health insurance companies and accreditation organizations) and do not have a central resource that provides information about any new codes that can generate additional revenue for their organization.


We learned about the importance of the efficiency of workflow, and how adding a new portal can cause workflow issues. To mitigate these issues, integration with Electronic Medical Record (EMR) and Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems allow for an overall ease of use and simplification of billing for insurance, resulting in time savings and increased revenue.




Based on clinician answers to our questions, patient engagement in the clinic and at home is crucial to success in treatment, especially in an increasingly digital world. The clinically validated questionnaires, breathing exercises and ecological momentary assessments included in our platform were more appealing to clinicians than the biometric aspect. Financially, the opportunity to increase engagement while delivering monetary value through new Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) codes is appealing to providers. With the introduction of behavioral health integration and collaborative care in physical health settings, it will be difficult for providers to fully implement these workflows without technology due to the volume of patient information.


We found a customer need for the technology solution we created to improve patient behavioral health outcomes while providing insurance reimbursable workflows for the provider. Since our technology allows for scalable behavioral health integration and collaborative care in all care settings, we determined our product is a scalable business opportunity.


The broad impact of our technology promotes behavioral health access and engagement in all care settings to improve outcomes, overall wellness, and cost of care. This has an impact on the treatment for both behavioral and physical health conditions. We found clinicians and organizations that treat patients with physical health conditions who either have or are at-risk for mental health conditions are a growing market for our product.


 


Last Modified: 03/31/2019
Modified by: Arjun Ramakrishnan
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: For the duration of the NSF I-CORPS program, our team interviewed 108 medical professionals to explore the potential for commercialization of NeuroFlow's digital health platform that analyzes real-time patient data through a variety of inputs relating to mental state. There are several stakeholders who would benefit from this platform, including clinicians and patients. The aim was to understand and identify optimal customer segments to enable commercialization efforts. Initial customer segments included private practices and hospital systems focusing on behavioral health with the assumptions of insurance coverage having an impact on patient care decisions. While the engagement and compliance features in our platform resonated with behavioral health clinicians, we found the cost savings per patient and the potential for accelerating treatment via remote patient monitoring were appealing to providers. We quickly learned mental health clinicians don?t always accept insurance due to the low reimbursement rates, however non-behavioral health clinicians are more likely to accept insurance. Additional potential customer segments expanded to payors, community behavioral health and physical health settings. We additionally sought input from medical professionals in these segments, such as primary care physicians and pain providers. After speaking with these additional segments, we learned many providers aren?t familiar with new CPT codes surrounding behavioral health (Current Procedural Terminology - a medical code set that is used to report medical, surgical, and diagnostic procedures and services to entities such as physicians, health insurance companies and accreditation organizations) and do not have a central resource that provides information about any new codes that can generate additional revenue for their organization. We learned about the importance of the efficiency of workflow, and how adding a new portal can cause workflow issues. To mitigate these issues, integration with Electronic Medical Record (EMR) and Electronic Health Record (EHR) systems allow for an overall ease of use and simplification of billing for insurance, resulting in time savings and increased revenue. Based on clinician answers to our questions, patient engagement in the clinic and at home is crucial to success in treatment, especially in an increasingly digital world. The clinically validated questionnaires, breathing exercises and ecological momentary assessments included in our platform were more appealing to clinicians than the biometric aspect. Financially, the opportunity to increase engagement while delivering monetary value through new Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) codes is appealing to providers. With the introduction of behavioral health integration and collaborative care in physical health settings, it will be difficult for providers to fully implement these workflows without technology due to the volume of patient information. We found a customer need for the technology solution we created to improve patient behavioral health outcomes while providing insurance reimbursable workflows for the provider. Since our technology allows for scalable behavioral health integration and collaborative care in all care settings, we determined our product is a scalable business opportunity. The broad impact of our technology promotes behavioral health access and engagement in all care settings to improve outcomes, overall wellness, and cost of care. This has an impact on the treatment for both behavioral and physical health conditions. We found clinicians and organizations that treat patients with physical health conditions who either have or are at-risk for mental health conditions are a growing market for our product.
